quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Forces with Air Resistance
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 7: Simplified Air Resistance Problems (10 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A $0.50\ \text{kg}$ ball is dropped from rest. Air resistance exerts a constant upward force of $0.5\ \text{N}$. What is the ball's acceleration just after release?
questions.explanation: Weight $= mg = 4.9\ \text{N}$ down. Net force $= 4.9 - 0.5 = 4.4\ \text{N}$ down. Acceleration $a = F_{\text{net}}/m = 4.4/0.50 = 8.8\ \text{m/s}^2$ down.

questions.question: A skydiver reaches terminal velocity when the force of air resistance equals her weight. If her mass is $70\ \text{kg}$, what is the air resistance force at terminal velocity?
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, net force $= 0$, so air resistance $=$ weight $= mg = 70 \times 9.8 = 686\ \text{N}$ upward.

questions.question: A $2.0\ \text{kg}$ projectile is launched upward at $40\ \text{m/s}$. If air resistance exerts a constant $1.0\ \text{N}$ force downward during its entire flight, how much lower does it go compared to the no-air-resistance case?
questions.explanation: Without air: $\Delta y = 40^2/(2\times9.8) \approx 81.63\ \text{m}$. With air: effective $a = (mg+1.0)/m = 10.3\ \text{m/s}^2$, $\Delta y = 40^2/(2\times10.3) \approx 77.67\ \text{m}$. Difference $\approx 4.0\ \text{m}$.

questions.question: A $1500\ \text{kg}$ car travels at constant speed. The engine provides $2000\ \text{N}$ forward force. If air resistance is the only opposing force, what is the air resistance force?
questions.explanation: Constant speed $\Rightarrow$ net force $=0$. So air resistance force $=$ engine force $= 2000\ \text{N}$ backward.

questions.question: A $0.20\ \text{kg}$ coffee filter falls and reaches terminal velocity. At terminal velocity, what is the net force on the filter?
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity means constant velocity $\Rightarrow$ acceleration $=0 \Rightarrow$ net force $=0$ by Newton's first law.

questions.question: A $60\ \text{kg}$ cyclist rides at constant $10\ \text{m/s}$ on level ground. If air resistance is the only opposing force and is measured to be $80\ \text{N}$, what power is she producing?
questions.explanation: Constant speed $\Rightarrow$ her forward force $=$ air resistance $=80\ \text{N}$. Power $= F \times v = 80 \times 10 = 800\ \text{W}$.

questions.question: A $5.0\ \text{kg}$ object is dropped with air resistance. At one instant, it has acceleration $8.0\ \text{m/s}^2$ downward. What is the air resistance force at that instant?
questions.explanation: Net force $= m a = 5.0 \times 8.0 = 40\ \text{N}$ down. Weight $= 49\ \text{N}$ down. So $49 - F_{\text{air}} = 40 \Rightarrow F_{\text{air}} = 9.0\ \text{N}$ up.

questions.question: A $0.10\ \text{kg}$ badminton shuttlecock is hit upward. Air resistance exerts a constant $0.05\ \text{N}$ force downward. Compared to vacuum, it reaches:
questions.explanation: Air resistance adds to gravity, increasing downward acceleration, so it doesn't go as high as in vacuum.

questions.question: A $1200\ \text{kg}$ car coasts from $30\ \text{m/s}$ to rest. Air resistance is a constant $400\ \text{N}$ plus rolling friction $200\ \text{N}$. Using energy, find the stopping distance.
questions.explanation: Initial KE $= \frac{1}{2} \times 1200 \times 30^2 = 540,000\ \text{J}$. Total opposing force $= 400+200=600\ \text{N}$. Work $= Fd \Rightarrow 540,000 = 600d \Rightarrow d=900\ \text{m}$.

questions.question: A $0.050\ \text{kg}$ ping pong ball falls at terminal velocity. If air resistance is $0.49\ \text{N}$ upward, what is the ball's net force?
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity means constant velocity $\Rightarrow$ acceleration $=0 \Rightarrow$ net force $=0$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand forces with air resistance and terminal velocity concepts.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid grasp of equilibrium and constant force motion with air resistance.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Review net force calculations and terminal velocity conditions.
scoreMessages.0: Review Newton's laws, especially net force = ma and equilibrium (net force = 0).
